en: The Cherry Lane Theatre is the oldest continuously running off-Broadway theater in New York City.
pr: Th' Cherry Lane Theatre be th' oldest sailin' off-Broadway stage in New York City, still chartin' new courses.

en: The theater is located at 38 Commerce Street between Barrow and Bedford Streets in the West Village neighborhood of Greenwich Village, Manhattan, New York City.
pr: Th' theater be docked at 38 Commerce Street 'twixt Barrow 'n Bedford in West Village, Greenwich Village, Manhattan.

en: The Cherry Lane Theatre contains a 179-seat main stage and a 60-seat studio.
pr: Cherry Lane be harborin' a grand 179-seat main deck 'n a smaller 60-seat studio.

en: The building was constructed as a farm silo in 1817, and also served as a brewery, tobacco warehouse and box factory before Evelyn Vaughn, William S. Rainey, Reginald Travers & Edna St. Vincent Millay converted the structure into a theater they christened the Cherry Lane Playhouse.
pr: Built as a farm silo in 1817, this buildin' once served as a brewery, tobacco warehouse, 'n box factory 'til it were christened Cherry Lane Playhouse by th' bold Evelyn Vaughn, William S. Rainey, Reginald Travers 'n Edna St. Vincent Millay.

en: It opened in 1923.
pr: It opened its doors in 1923.

en: Its first reviewed show was Saturday Night by Robert Presnell, which opened on February 9, 1924.
pr: Th' first reviewed show t' sail was Saturday Night by Robert Presnell, cast off on February 9, 1924.

en: This was followed by the plays The Man Who Ate Popomack, by W. J. Turner, directed by Reginald Travers, on March 24, 1924; and The Way of the World by William Congreve, produced by the Cherry Lane Players Inc., opening November 17, 1924.
pr: This be followed by th' plays The Man Who Ate Popomack, by W.J. Turner, with Cap'n Travers at th' helm, on March 24, 1924; and The Way o' the World by William Congreve, hoistin' its sails on November 17, 1924 by th' Cherry Lane Players Inc.

en: The theatre received a significant makeover in 1954 when it acquired much of the expensive furnishings sold off by Rockefeller Center's failing Center Theatre.
pr: Th' theater got itself a grand makeover in 1954 when it salvaged fine furnishings from Rockefeller Center's sinkin' Center Theatre.

en: Shortly afterwards, he married Margaret, daughter of John FitzAlan, 1st Baron Arundel.

en: The Fitzalan family, like that of de Ros, was well-connected at the local and national level.

en: They were implacably opposed to King Richard II, and this may have soured Richard's opinion of the young de Ros.

en: The softer rock was eroded by wind and water, leaving the hard cap rock on top of pillars, forming the present-day fairy chimneys.

en: Daniel Boone (November 2, 1734 – September 26, 1820) was an American pioneer and frontiersman.
pr: Daniel Boone (November 2, 1734 – September 26, 1820) be an American pioneer and frontiersman.

en: In 1775, he blazed the Wilderness Road through the Cumberland Gap into Kentucky, despite resistance from Native Americans; by the end of the 18th century, more than 200,000 people had entered Kentucky by following the route marked by Boone.
pr: In 1775, he blazed the Wilderness Road through the Cumberland Gap into Kentucky, despite resistance from native folk; by century’s end, more than 200,000 souls had entered Kentucky by followin' Boone’s trail.

en: He was adopted into the Shawnee tribe in 1778 but resigned after his son was killed by members.
pr: He be adopted by the Shawnee tribe in 1778 but left after his son be slain by members.

en: In April 1781, Boone was elected to the Virginia General Assembly.
pr: In April 1781, Boone be elected to the Virginia General Assembly.

en: An account of his adventures was published in 1784, making him famous in America and Europe.
pr: A tale of his adventures be published in 1784, makin' him famous in America and across the seas.

en: After the Revolutionary War, he worked as a surveyor and merchant but went into debt as a Kentucky land speculator.
pr: After the War o' Independence, he worked as a surveyor and merchant but sank into debt as a Kentucky land speculator.

en: In 1799, Boone resettled in Missouri, where he spent most of his remaining life.
pr: In 1799, Boone resettled in Missouri, where he spent most o' his remainin' days.

en: After his death, he was the subject of works of fiction; his adventures helped create the archetypal frontier hero of American folklore.
pr: After his passin', he became the subject o' many tales; his exploits helped craft the archetype o' the frontier hero in American lore.

en: The Edmonds Band Rotunda is a rotunda in Christchurch, New Zealand.
pr: The Edmonds Band Rotunda be a rotunda in Christchurch, New Zealand.

en: Created by baking powder manufacturer Thomas Edmonds in 1929 to celebrate his 50th year of living in the city, it was used initially as a place for brass bands to play music.
pr: Built by Thomas Edmonds, a maker o' bakin' powder, in 1929 to mark his 50th year in the city, it first served as a spot fer brass bands t' play their tunes.

en: It was converted to a restaurant in the 1980s.
pr: It be turned into a tavern in the 1980s.

en: The 2010 and 2011 Christchurch earthquakes caused significant damage to the rotunda, and it had to be deconstructed.
pr: The great quakes o' 2010 and 2011 ravaged the rotunda, and it had t' be taken down.

en: After being rebuilt, the rotunda re-opened in 2021 and is now used for performances.
pr: After bein' rebuilt, the rotunda opened again in 2021, now servin' fer performances.

en: Isolated on various islands around the Indian Ocean, kestrel populations evolved into different species, like Darwin's finches.
pr: Isolated on islands 'round the Indian Ocean, kestrel populations evolved into many different kinds, like Darwin's finches.

en: Behaviour remains similar to other small species of Falco (such as the common kestrel, Falco tinnunculus) except on (originally) forested Mauritius where kestrels hunt arboreally more like hawks.
pr: Their ways be similar t' other small hawks (like the common kestrel, Falco tinnunculus) 'cept on Mauritius, where kestrels hunt in the trees like hawks.

en: Due to the scarcity of mammals on oceanic islands, several species have adopted a diet containing many Phelsuma and other geckos.
pr: With few mammals on ocean islands, some species feast on Phelsuma and other geckos.

en: The species can be distinguished by coloration, but all except the banded kestrel share rich brown wings with black spotting.
pr: These kinds can be told apart by color, though all but the banded kestrel share rich brown wings with black spots.

en: Sexes are alike in color except in the spotted kestrel, where differences are minor.
pr: Male and female be alike in color save fer the spotted kestrel, where the differences be slight.

en: As usual in birds of prey, females are larger than males; considerably so in some of these species as this assists resource partitioning.
pr: As be common in birds o' prey, females be bigger than males; far more so in some kinds, as this helps divvy up resources.

en: A History of Japanese Literature (1899), written by the diplomat and Japanese and Korean scholar William George Aston, is the oldest comprehensive survey of the large Japanese literature having been published in English.
pr: A History o' Japanese Literature (1899), penned by th' diplomat an' scholar o' Japan an' Korea, William George Aston, be th' oldest comprehensive survey o' th' vast Japanese literature ever published in English.

en: Its range is from the Archaic period (before A.D. 700) until the so-called Tokio period in the second half of the nineteenth century and covers all lyrics, poetry, prose and children's stories.

en: The Ping River, Thailand's largest, reached its highest water levels in 50 years peaking at 5.3 meters on Saturday.

en: Chiang Mai is the largest city in northern Thailand, the capital of Chiang Mai province and the second largest city in Thailand.

en: It is 700 km (435 mi) north of Bangkok in a mountainous region called the Thai highlands and has a population of 1.2 million people as of 2022, which is more than 66 percent of the total population of Chiang Mai province (1.8 million).

en: Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour (usually wheat) and water, usually by baking.
pr: Bread be a fine food made from dough o' flour (mostly wheat) an' water, usually by bakin'.

en: Throughout recorded history and around the world, it has been an important part of many cultures' diet.
pr: Th' world over an' through history, 'tis been a mighty part o' many a culture's grub.

en: It is one of the oldest human-made foods, having been of significance since the dawn of agriculture, and plays an essential role in both religious rituals and secular culture.
pr: 'Tis one o' th' oldest vittles man ever made, important since th' dawn o' farmin', an' a key role in both religious rites an' every-day ways.

en: Bread may be leavened by naturally occurring microbes (e.g. sourdough), chemicals (e.g. baking soda), industrially produced yeast, or high-pressure aeration, which creates the gas bubbles that fluff up bread.
pr: Bread can be made fluffy by natural beasties (like sourdough), chemicals (like bakin' soda), man-made yeast, or high-pressure air blowin', makin' them bubbles that fluff it up.

en: In many countries, commercial bread often contains additives to improve flavor, texture, color, shelf life, nutrition, and ease of production.
pr: In many lands, store-bought bread be full o' add-ins to better th' taste, feel, color, lastin' power, health, an' easiness o' makin'.

en: A door is a hinged or otherwise movable barrier that allows ingress (entry) into and egress (exit) from an enclosure.
pr: A door be a hinged or movin' plank that lets folk in or out o' an enclosure.

en: The created opening in the wall is a doorway or portal.
pr: Th' hole in th' wall be called a doorway or portal.

en: A door's essential and primary purpose is to provide security by controlling access to the doorway (portal).
pr: A door's main purpose be providin' security by guardin' access to th' portal.

en: Conventionally, it is a panel that fits into the doorway of a building, room, or vehicle.
pr: Usually, 'tis a plank that fits th' doorway o' a buildin', room, or ship.

en: Doors are generally made of a material suited to the door's task.
pr: Doors be made o' what be best fer th' job.

en: They are commonly attached by hinges, but can move by other means, such as slides or counterbalancing.
pr: They usually swing on hinges, but can slide or balance in strange ways too.

en: The door may be able to move in various ways (at angles away from the doorway/portal, by sliding on a plane parallel to the frame, by folding in angles on a parallel plane, or by spinning along an axis at the center of the frame) to allow or prevent ingress or egress.
pr: A door can open in many ways (swingin', slidin', foldin', or spinnin' on an axis) to let in or keep out folks.

en: In most cases, a door's interior matches its exterior side.
pr: In most cases, th' inside o' a door looks like th' outside.

en: But in other cases (e.g., a vehicle door) the two sides are radically different.
pr: But in other cases (like a ship door) th' sides may be as different as day an' night.

en: A window is an opening in a wall, door, roof, or vehicle that allows the exchange of light and may also allow the passage of sound and sometimes air.
pr: A window be an openin' in a wall, door, roof, or ship that lets in light an' sometimes sound an' air.

en: Modern windows are usually glazed or covered in some other transparent or translucent material, a sash set in a frame in the opening; the sash and frame are also referred to as a window.
pr: Modern windows be usually glazed or covered with clear stuff, with a sash set in a frame; both together be called a window.

en: Many glazed windows may be opened, to allow ventilation, or closed to exclude inclement weather.
pr: Many a glazed window can open fer fresh air, or be shut tight against foul weather.

en: Windows may have a latch or similar mechanism to lock the window shut or to hold it open by various amounts.
pr: Windows may have a latch or somethin' to lock it shut or hold it open a bit.

en: A chair is a type of seat, typically designed for one person and consisting of one or more legs, a flat or slightly angled seat and a back-rest.

en: It may be made of wood, metal, or synthetic materials, and may be padded or upholstered in various colors and fabrics.
pr: It might be made o' wood, metal, or strange new materials, an' could be padded or covered in colors an' cloth.

en: The face is the front of an animal's head that features the eyes, nose and mouth, and through which animals express many of their emotions.
pr: Th' face be th' front o' an animal's head, with eyes, nose, an' mouth, showin' many feelin's.

en: The face is crucial for human identity, and damage such as scarring or developmental deformities may affect the psyche adversely.
pr: Th' face be key to a person's self, an' harm like scarrin' or deformity can trouble th' mind.

en: Emotions are physical and mental states brought on by neurophysiological changes, variously associated with thoughts, feelings, behavioral responses, and a degree of pleasure or displeasure.
pr: Emotions be feelin's o' th' body an' mind, roused by changes within, tied to thoughts, acts, an' pleasure or pain.

en: There is no scientific consensus on a definition.
pr: There be no grand answer from th' scholars on what emotions truly be.

en: Emotions are often intertwined with mood, temperament, personality, disposition, or creativity.
pr: Emotions be oft mixed with mood, temper, character, disposition, or creativeness.

en: Pleasure is experience that feels good, that involves the enjoyment of something.
pr: Pleasure be a feelin' that brings joy, a savin' o' somethin' pleasant.

en: It contrasts with pain or suffering, which are forms of feeling bad.
pr: Pleasure be different from pain or sufferin', which be feelin's o' bad sorts.

en: It is closely related to value, desire and action: humans and other conscious animals find pleasure enjoyable, positive or worthy of seeking.
pr: Pleasure be tied to worth, want, an' doin': folk an' other beasties find it joyful, good, or worth chasin'.

en: A great variety of activities may be experienced as pleasurable, like eating, having sex, listening to music or playing games.
pr: Many a thing brings pleasure, like eatin', lovin', listenin' to music, or gamin'.

en: Pleasure is part of various other mental states such as ecstasy, euphoria and flow.
pr: Pleasure be part o' other states o' mind like ecstasy, euphoria, an' flow.

en: Happiness and well-being are closely related to pleasure but not identical with it.
pr: Happiness an' well-bein' be close kin to pleasure but not th' same.

en: There is no general agreement as to whether pleasure should be understood as a sensation, a quality of experiences, an attitude to experiences or otherwise.
pr: There be no clear answer on if pleasure be a feelin', a quality o' things, or an attitude, or else.

en: Pleasure plays a central role in the family of philosophical theories known as hedonism.
pr: Pleasure be central in th' thinkin' family o' hedonism.

en: Happiness is a complex and multifaceted emotion that encompasses a range of positive feelings, from contentment to intense joy.
pr: Happiness be a tricky, many-sided feelin', from contentment to deep joy.

en: It is often associated with positive life experiences, such as achieving goals, spending time with loved ones, or engaging in enjoyable activities.
pr: 'Tis often linked to good life moments, like reachin' goals, bein' with loved ones, or doin' fun things.

en: However, happiness can also arise spontaneously, without any apparent external cause.
pr: But happiness can sometimes come on its own, with no clear cause from th' outside.

en: A smile is a facial expression formed primarily by flexing the muscles at the sides of the mouth.
pr: A smile be a face twist made by pullin' th' sides o' th' mouth.

en: Some smiles include a contraction of the muscles at the corner of the eyes, an action known as a Duchenne smile.
pr: Some smiles involve pullin' th' muscles at th' eye corners, known as a Duchenne smile.

en: Among humans, a smile expresses delight, sociability, happiness, joy, or amusement.
pr: To humans, a smile shows delight, friendliness, joy, or amusement.

en: It is distinct from a similar but usually involuntary expression of anxiety known as a grimace.
pr: 'Tis different from th' involuntary anxious face known as a grimace.

en: Although cross-cultural studies have shown that smiling is a means of communication throughout the world, there are large differences among different cultures, religions, and societies, with some using smiles to convey confusion, embarrassment or awkwardness.
pr: Though smilin' be a way o' communicatin' worldwide, cultures differ much, with some usin' smiles fer confusion, embarrassment, or awkwardness.

en: Private Browsing is a useful feature of Firefox, but only if you understand the protection it offers.
pr: Private Browsin' be a useful feature o' Firefox, but only if ye understand the protection it offers.

en: It helps you keep your online activity private from others who use Firefox on the same computer, but it won't make you invisible online.
pr: It helps ye keep yer online activity private from others who use Firefox on the same computer, but 'twon't make ye invisible online.

en: Myth 1: Private Browsing makes you anonymous on the Internet.
pr: Myth 1: Private Browsin' makes ye anonymous on the Internet.

en: Reality: Private Browsing does not mask your identity or activity online.

en: Websites and internet service providers can still gather information about your visit, even if you are not signed in.

en: If you use your device at work, your company may be able to monitor the websites you visit.

en: If you surf the Web at home, your cable company (or their partners) may have access to your browsing information.
pr: If ye surf the Web at home, yer cable crew (or thar partners) may 'ave access t' yer browsin' information.

en: Only a Virtual Private Network (VPN) can mask your location and encrypt your online activity, keeping your identity and data safe from prying eyes.

en: Myth 2: Private Browsing removes all traces of your browsing activity from your computer.

en: Reality: Private Browsing works by letting you browse without saving passwords, cookies and browsing history in a Private Window.

en: If you download a file from a website, it will remain on your computer, but it will not appear in the download manager in Firefox.

en: If you bookmark a website while in a Private Window, it will remain in your bookmark list.

en: Myth 3: Private Browsing doesnt display any browsing history.

en: Reality: Private Browsing will, by default, display visited sites and bookmarks as you type in the address bar.

en: English is a West Germanic language in the Indo-European language family, whose speakers, called Anglophones, originated in early medieval England on the island of Great Britain.
pr: English be a West Germanic language in the Indo-European language family, whose speakers, called Anglophones, originated in early medieval England on the island o' Great Britain.

en: The namesake of the language is the Angles, one of the ancient Germanic peoples that migrated to Britain.
pr: The namesake o' the language be the Angles, one o' the ancient Germanic peoples dat migrated t' Britain.

en: It is the most spoken language in the world, primarily due to the global influences of the former British Empire (succeeded by the Commonwealth of Nations) and the United States.
pr: 'tis the most spoken language in the world, primarily due t' the global influences o' the former British Empire (succeeded by the Commonwealth o' Nations) 'n the United States.

en: English is the third-most spoken native language, after Standard Chinese and Spanish; it is also the most widely learned second language in the world, with more second-language speakers than native speakers.
pr: English be the third-most spoken native language, aft Standard Chinese 'n Spanish; 'tis also the most widely learned second language in the world, wit' more second-language speakers than native speakers.

en: English is either the official language or one of the official languages in 59 sovereign states (such as India, Ireland, and Canada).
pr: English be either the official language or one o' the official languages in 59 sovereign states (such as India, Ireland, 'n Canada).

en: In some other countries, it is the sole or dominant language for historical reasons without being explicitly defined by law (such as in the United States and United Kingdom).
pr: In some other countries, 'tis the sole or dominant language fer historical reasons without bein' explicitly defined by code o' conduct (such as in the United States 'n United Kingdom).

en: It is a co-official language of the United Nations, the European Union, and many other international and regional organisations.
pr: 'tis a co-official language o' the United Nations, the European Union, 'n many other international 'n regional organisations.

en: It has also become the de facto lingua franca of diplomacy, science, technology, international trade, logistics, tourism, aviation, entertainment, and the Internet.
pr: It has also become the de facto lingua franca o' diplomacy, science, technology, international trade, logistics, tourism, aviation, entertainment, 'n the Internet.

en: English accounts for at least 70% of total speakers of the Germanic language branch, and as of 2021, Ethnologue estimated that there were over 1.5 billion speakers worldwide.
pr: English accounts fer at least 70% o' total speakers o' the Germanic language branch, 'n as o' 2021, Ethnologue estimated dat thar were o'er 1.5 billion speakers worldwide.

en: There is nothing surprising in this.
pr: Thar be naught surprisin' in dis.

en: If they but knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.
pr: If they but knew it, nigh-on all maties in thar degree, some time or other, cherish mighty nigh-on the same feelings towards the ocean wit' me.

en: There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by wharves as Indian isles by coral reefscommerce surrounds it with her surf.
pr: Thar now be yer insular city o' the Manhattoes, belted round by wharves as Indian isles by coral reefscommerce surrounds it wit' her surf.

en: Right and left, the streets take you waterward.
pr: Right 'n left, the roads take ye waterward.

en: Its extreme downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by waves, and cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of sight of land.
pr: Its extreme downtown be the battery, where dat noble mole be washed by waves, 'n cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out o' sight o' land.

en: Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.
pr: Look at the crowds o' water-gazers thar.

en: Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.
pr: Circumambulate the city o' a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.

en: Go from Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitsehall, northward.
pr: Go from Corlears Hook t' Coenties Slip, 'n from thence, by Whitehall, northward.

en: What do you see?Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean reveries.
pr: Wha' do ye see?Posted like silent sentinels all around the town, stand thousands upon thousands o' mortal maties fixed in ocean reveries.

en: Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better seaward peep.
pr: Some careenin' against the spiles; some seated upon the pier-heads; some lookin' o'er the bulwarks o' ships from China; some high aloft in the riggin', as if strivin' t' get a still better seaward peep.

en: But these are all landsmen; of week days pent up in lath and plastertied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to desks.
pr: But these be all landsmen; o' week days pent up in lath 'n plastertied t' counters, nailed t' benches, clinched t' desks.

en: How then is this?
pr: How then be dis?

en: Are the green fields gone?
pr: Be the green fields gone?

en: What do they here?
pr: Wha' do they here?

en: But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and seemingly bound for a dive.
pr: But look! here come more crowds, pacin' straight fer the water, 'n seemingly bound fer a dive.

en: Strange!
pr: Strange!

en: Nothing will content them but the extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of yonder warehouses will not suffice.
pr: Naught will content 'em but the extremest limit o' the land; loiterin' under the shady lee o' yonder warehouses will nah suffice.

en: No.
pr: No.

en: They must get just as nigh the water as they possibly can without falling in.
pr: They must get jus' as nigh the water as they possibly can without fallin' in.

en: And there they standmiles of themleagues.
pr: 'n thar they standmiles o' 'emleagues.

en: Inlanders all, they come from lanes and alleys, streets and avenuesnorth, east, south, and west.
pr: Inlanders all, they come from lanes 'n alleys, roads 'n avenuesnorth, east, south, 'n west.

en: Yet here they all unite.
pr: Yet here they all unite.

en: Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the needles of the compasses of all those ships attract them thither?
pr: Tell me, does the magnetic virtue o' the needles o' the compasses o' all those ships attract 'em thither?

en: Once more.
pr: Once more.

en: Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes.
pr: Say ye be in the country; in some high land o' lakes.

en: Take almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down in a dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream.
pr: Take nigh-on any path ye please, 'n ten t' one it carries ye down in a dale, 'n leaves ye thar by a pool in the stream.

en: There is magic in it.
pr: Thar be magic in it.

en: Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his deepest reveriesstand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going, and he will infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all that region.
pr: Let the most absent-minded o' maties be plunged in his deepest reveriesstand dat scallywag on his legs, set his feet a-goin', 'n he will infallibly lead ye t' water, if water thar be in all dat region.

en: Should you ever be athirst in the great American desert, try this experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplised with a metaphysical professor.
pr: Shall ye ever be athirst in the great American desert, try dis experiment, if yer caravan happen t' be supplied wit' a metaphysical professor.

en: Yes, as every one knows, meditation and water are wedded for ever.
pr: Aye, as every one knows, meditation 'n water be wedded fer ever.

en: But here is an artist.
pr: But here be an artist.

en: He desires to paint you the dreamiest, shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all the valley of the Saco.
pr: He desires t' paint ye the dreamiest, shadiest, quietest, most enchantin' bit o' romantic landscape in all the valley o' the Saco.

en: What is the chief element he employs?
pr: Wha' be the chief element he employs?

en: There stand his trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a crucifix were within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his cattle; and up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.
pr: Thar stand his trees, each wit' a hollow hold, as if a hermit 'n a crucifix were within; 'n here sleeps his meadow, 'n thar sleep his cattle; 'n up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.

en: Deep into distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of mountains bathed in their hill-side blue.
pr: Deep into distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reachin' t' overlappin' spurs o' mountains bathed in thar hill-side blue.

en: But though the picture lies thus tranced, and though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs like leaves upon this shepherds head, yet all were vain, unless the shepherds eye were fixed upon the magic stream before him.
pr: But though the picture lies thus tranced, 'n though dis pine-tree shakes down its sighs like leaves upon dis shepherds head, yet all were vain, unless the shepherds eye were fixed upon the magic stream afore 'im.

en: Go visit the Prairies in June, when for scores on scores of miles you wade knee-deep among Tiger-lilieswhat is the one charm wanting?Waterthere is not a drop of water there!
pr: Go visit the Prairies in June, when fer scores on scores o' miles ye wade knee-deep among Tiger-lilieswha' be the one charm wantin'?Waterthar ain't a drop o' water thar!

en: Were Niagara but a cataract of sand, would you travel your thousand miles to see it?
pr: Were Niagara but a cataract o' sand, would ye travel yer thousand miles t' see it?

en: Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway Beach?
pr: Why did the poor poet o' Tennessee, upon suddenly receivin' two handfuls o' silver, deliberate whether t' buy 'im a coat, which he sadly needed, or invest his doubloons in a pedestrian trip t' Rockaway Beach?

en: Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?
pr: Why be well-nigh every robust healthy lad wit' a robust healthy soul in 'im, at some time or other crazy t' go t' sea?

en: Why upon your first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out of sight of land?
pr: Why upon yer first voyage as a passenger, did ye yourself feel such a mystical vibration, when first told dat ye 'n yer ship were now out o' sight o' land?

en: Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy?
pr: Why did the ole Persians hold the sea holy?

en: Why did the Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove?
pr: Why did the Greeks give it a separate deity, 'n owns matey o' Jove?

en: Surely all this is not without meaning.
pr: Surely all dis ain't without meanin'.

en: And still deeper the meaning of that story of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the tormenting, mild image he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and was drowned.
pr: 'n still deeper the meanin' o' dat tale o' Narcissus, who 'cause he could nah grasp the tormentin', mild image he saw in the foun'ain, plunged into it 'n was drowned.

en: But that same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and oceans.
pr: But dat same image, we ourselves see in all rivers 'n oceans.

en: It is the image of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this is the key to it all.
pr: I take it dat dis part o' the bill must 'ave run somethin' like dis:

en: It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet.
pr: It seemed the great Black Parliament sittin' in Tophet.

en: A hundred black faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black Angel of Doom was beating a book in a pulpit.
pr: A hundred black faces turned round in thar rows t' peer; 'n beyond, a black Angel o' Doom was beatin' a book in a pulpit.

en: It was a negro church; and the preachers text was about the blackness of darkness, and the weeping and wailing and teeth-gnashing there.
pr: 'twas a negro church; 'n the preachers text was about the blackness o' darkness, 'n the weepin' 'n wailin' 'n teeth-gnashin' thar.

en: Ha, Ishmael, muttered I, backing out, Wretched entertainment at the sign of The Trap!
pr: Har, Ishmael, muttered I, backin' out, Wretched entertainment at the sign o' The Trap!

en: Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the docks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a swinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly representing a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words underneath'The Spouter Inn:Peter Coffin.'
pr: Movin' on, I at last came t' a dim sort o' light nah far from the docks, 'n heard a forlorn creakin' in the air; 'n lookin' up, saw a swingin' sign o'er the door wit' a white paintin' upon it, faintly representin' a tall straight jet o' misty spray, 'n these words underneath'The Spouter Inn:Peter Dead man's chest.'

en: Coffin?Spouter?Rather ominous in that particular connexion, thought I.
pr: Dead man's chest?Spouter?Rather ominous in dat particular connexion, thought I.

en: But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I suppose this Peter here is an emigrant from there.
pr: But 'tis a common name in Nantucket, they say, 'n I suppose dis Pistol-Packin' Peter here be an emigrant from thar.

en: As the light looked so dim, and the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and the dilapidated little wooden house itself looked as if it might have been carted here from the ruins of some burnt district, and as the swinging sign had a poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought that here was the very spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea coffee.
pr: As the light looked so dim, 'n the place, fer the time, looked quiet enough, 'n the dilapidated wee wooden house itself looked as if it might 'ave been carted here from the ruins o' some burnt district, 'n as the swingin' sign had a poverty-stricken sort o' creak t' it, I thought dat here was the mighty spot fer cheap lodgings, 'n the best o' pea black brew.

en: It was a queer sort of placea gable-ended old house, one side palsied as it were, and leaning over sadly.
pr: 'twas a queer sort o' placea gable-ended ole house, one side palsied as it were, 'n careenin' o'er sadly.

en: It stood on a sharp bleak corner, where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse howling than ever it did about poor Pauls tossed craft.
pr: It stood on a sharp bleak corner, where dat tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse howlin' than ever it did about poor Pauls tossed craft.

en: Euroclydon, nevertheless, is a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with his feet on the hob quietly toasting for bed.
pr: Euroclydon, nevertheless, be a mighty pleasant zephyr t' any one in-doors, wit' his feet on the hob quietly toastin' fer hammock.

en: 'In judging of that tempestuous wind called Euroclydon,' says an old writerof whose works I possess the only copy extant'it maketh a marvellous difference, whether thou lookest out at it from a glass window where the frost is all on the outside, or whether thou observest it from that sashless window, where the frost is on both sides, and of which the wight Death is the only glazier.'
pr: 'In judgin' o' dat tempestuous wind called Euroclydon,' says an ole writero' whose works I possess the only copy extant'it maketh a marvellous difference, whether thou lookest out at it from a glass window where the frost be all on the outside, or whether thou observest it from dat sashless window, where the frost be on both sides, 'n o' which the wight Death be the only glazier.'

en: True enough, thought I, as this passage occurred to my mindold black-letter, thou reasonest well.
pr: True enough, thought I, as dis passage occurred t' me mindole black-letter, thou reasonest well.

en: Yes, these eyes are windows, and this body of mine is the house.
pr: Aye, these eyes be windows, 'n dis body o' mine be the house.

en: What a pity they didnt stop up the chinks and the crannies though, and thrust in a little lint here and there.
pr: Wha' a pity they didnt stop up the chinks 'n the crannies though, 'n jab in a wee lint here 'n thar.

en: But its too late to make any improvements now.
pr: But its too late t' make any improvements now.

en: The universe is finished; the copestone is on, and the chips were carted off a million years ago.
pr: The universe be finished; the copestone be on, 'n the chips were carted off a million years ago.

en: Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth against the curbstone for his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with his shiverings, he might plug up both ears with rags, and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.
pr: Poor Lazarus thar, chatterin' his teeth against the curbstone fer his pillow, 'n shakin' off his tatters wit' his shiverings, he might plug up both ears wit' rags, 'n put a corn-cob into his mouth, 'n yet dat wouldna keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.

en: Euroclydon! says old Dives, in his red silken wrapper(he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! What a fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; what northern lights!
pr: Euroclydon! says ole Dives, in his red silken wrapper(he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! Wha' a fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; wha' northern lights!

en: Let them talk of their oriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the privilege of making my own summer with my own coals.
pr: Let 'em natter o' thar oriental summer climes o' everlastin' conservatories; give me the privilege o' makin' me owns summer wit' me owns coals.

en: But what thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holding them up to the grand northern lights?
pr: But wha' thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holdin' 'em up t' the grand northern lights?

en: Would not Lazarus rather be in Sumatra than here?
pr: Wouldna Lazarus rather be in Sumatra than here?

en: Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise along the line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit itself, in order to keep out this frost?
pr: Would he nah far rather lay 'im down lengthwise along the line o' the equator; aye, ye gods! go down t' the fiery pit itself, in order t' keep out dis frost?

en: Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before the door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should be moored to one of the Moluccas.
pr: Now, dat Lazarus shall lie marooned thar on the curbstone afore the door o' Dives, 'tis more wonderful than dat an iceberg best be moored t' one o' the Moluccas.

en: Yet Dives himself, he too lives like a Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a president of a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of orphans.
pr: Yet Dives hisself, he too lives like a Czar in an ice palace made o' frozen sighs, 'n bein' a cap'n o' a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears o' orphans.

en: But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there is plenty of that yet to come.
pr: But no more o' dis blubberin' now, we be goin' a-whalin', 'n thar be plenty o' dat yet t' come.

en: Yes, these eyes are windows, and this body of mine is the house.
pr: Aye, these eyes be windows, 'n this body o' mine be the house.

en: What a pity they didn't stop up the chinks and the crannies though, and thrust in a little lint here and there.
pr: Wha' a pity they didn't stop up the chinks 'n the crannies though, 'n jab in a wee bit o' lint here 'n there.

en: But it's too late to make any improvements now.
pr: But it be too late t' make any improvements now.

en: The universe is finished; the copestone is on, and the chips were carted off a million years ago.
pr: The universe be finished; the copestone be on, 'n the chips were carted off a million years ago.

en: Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth against the curbstone for his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with his shiverings, he might plug up both ears with rags, and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and yet that would not keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.
pr: Poor Lazarus thar, chatterin' his teeth against the curbstone fer his pillow, 'n shakin' off his tatters wit' his shiverin's, he might plug up both ears wit' rags, 'n put a corn-cob in his mouth, 'n yet dat wouldn't keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.

en: Euroclydon! says old Dives, in his red silken wrapper (he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! What a fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; what northern lights!
pr: Euroclydon! says ole Dives, in his red silken wrapper (he had a redder one afterwards) pooh, pooh! Wha' a fine frosty night; how Orion glitters; wha' northern lights!

en: Let them talk of their oriental summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the privilege of making my own summer with my own coals.
pr: Let 'em natter 'bout thar oriental summer climes o' everlastin' conservatories; give me the privilege o' makin' me own summer wit' me own coals.

en: But what thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holding them up to the grand northern lights?
pr: But wha' thinks Lazarus? Can he warm his blue hands by holdin' 'em up t' the grand northern lights?

en: Would not Lazarus rather be in Sumatra than here?
pr: Wouldn't Lazarus rather be in Sumatra than here?

en: Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise along the line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit itself, in order to keep out this frost?
pr: Would he nah far rather lay 'im down lengthwise along the line o' the equator; aye, ye gods! go down t' the fiery pit itself, t' keep out dis frost?

en: Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before the door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should be moored to one of the Moluccas.
pr: Now, dat Lazarus should lie marooned thar on the curbstone afore the door o' Dives, 'tis more wonderful than an iceberg bein' moored t' one o' the Moluccas.

en: Yet Dives himself, he too lives like a Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a president of a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of orphans.
pr: Yet Dives hisself, he too lives like a Czar in an ice palace made o' frozen sighs, 'n bein' a cap'n o' a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears o' orphans.

en: Let us scrape the ice from our frosted feet, and see what sort of a place this 'Spouter' may be.
pr: Let us scrape the ice from our frosted feet, 'n see wha' sort o' a place dis 'Spouter' may be.

en: I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific.
pr: I stuffed a shirt or two into me ole carpet-bag, tucked it under me arm, 'n started fer Cape Horn 'n the Pacific.

en: Quitting the good city of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford.
pr: Quittin' the good city o' ole Manhatto, I duly docked in New Bedford.

en: It was a Saturday night in December.
pr: 'twas a Saturday night in December.

en: Much was I disappointed upon learning that the little packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no way of reaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.
pr: Much was I disappointed upon learnin' dat the wee packet fer Nantucket had already sailed, 'n dat no way o' reachin' dat place would offer, till the followin' Monday.

en: As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop at this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as well be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing.
pr: As most young candidates fer the pains 'n penalties o' whalin' stop at dis same New Bedford, thence t' embark on thar voyage, it may as well be related dat I, fer one, had no idea o' so doin'.

en: For my mind was made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous old island, which amazingly pleased me.
pr: Fer me mind was made up t' sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, 'cause thar was a fine, boisterous somethin' about everythin' connected wit' dat famous ole island, which amazingly pleased me.

en: Let us scrape the ice from our frosted feet, and see what sort of a place this 'Spouter' may be.
pr: Let us scrape the ice from our frosted feet, 'n see wha' sort o' a place dis 'Spouter' may be.

en: I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific.
pr: I stuffed a shirt or two into me ole carpet-bag, tucked it under me arm, 'n started fer Cape Horn 'n the Pacific.

en: Quitting the good city of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford.
pr: Quittin' the good city o' ole Manhatto, I duly docked in New Bedford.

en: It was a Saturday night in December.
pr: 'Twas a Saturday night in December.

en: Much was I disappointed upon learning that the little packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no way of reaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.
pr: Much was I disappointed upon learnin' dat the wee packet fer Nantucket had already sailed, 'n dat no way o' reachin' dat place would offer, till the followin' Monday.

en: As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop at this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as well be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing.
pr: As most young candidates fer the pains 'n penalties o' whalin' stop at dis same New Bedford, thence t' embark on thar voyage, it may as well be related dat I, fer one, had no idea o' so doin'.

en: For my mind was made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because there was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected with that famous old island, which amazingly pleased me.
pr: Fer me mind was made up t' sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, 'cause thar was a fine, boisterous somethin' about everythin' connected wit' dat famous ole island, which amazingly pleased me.

en: Besides though New Bedford has of late been gradually monopolising the business of whaling, and though in this matter poor old Nantucket is now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great originalthe Tyre of this Carthage;the place where the first dead American whale was stranded.
pr: Besides though New Bedford has o' late been gradually monopolisin' the business o' whalin', 'n though in dis matter poor ole Nantucket be now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great originalthe Tyre o' dis Carthage;the place where the first dead American whale was marooned.

en: Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to give chase to the Leviathan?
pr: Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Maties, first sally out in canoes t' give chase t' the Leviathan?

en: And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported cobblestonesso goes the storyto throw at the whales, in order to discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the bowsprit?
pr: 'n where but from Nantucket, too, did dat first adventurous wee sloop put forth, partly laden wit' imported cobblestonesso goes the talet' throw at the whales, in order t' discover when they were nigh enough t' risk a harpoon from the bowsprit?

en: Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before me in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it became a matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile.
pr: Now havin' a night, a day, 'n still another night followin' afore me in New Bedford, ere I could embark fer me destined port, it became a matter o' concernment where I was t' eat 'n sleep meanwhile.

en: It was a very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly cold and cheerless.
pr: 'twas a mighty dubious-lookin', nay, a mighty dark 'n dismal night, bitingly cold 'n cheerless.

en: I knew no one in the place.
pr: I knew no one in the place.

en: With anxious grapnels I had sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,So, wherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of a dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the north with the darkness towards the southwherever in your wisdom you may conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to inquire the price, and dont be too particular.
pr: Wit' anxious grapnels I had sounded me pocket, 'n only brought up a few pieces o' silver,So, wherever ye go, Ishmael, said I t' meself, as I stood in the middle o' a dreary road shoulderin' me bag, 'n comparin' the gloom towards the north wit' the darkness towards the southwherever in yer wisdom ye may conclude t' lodge fer the night, me dear Ishmael, be sure t' inquire the price, 'n dont be too particular.

en: With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of 'The Crossed Harpoons'but it looked too expensive and jolly there.
pr: Wit' haltin' steps I paced the roads, 'n passed the sign o' 'The Crossed Harpoons'but it looked too expensive 'n jolly thar.

en: Further on, from the bright red windows of the 'Sword-Fish Inn,' there came such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the packed snow and ice from before the house, for everywhere else the congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,rather weary for me, when I struck my foot against the flinty projections, because from hard, remorseless service the soles of my boots were in a most miserable plight.
pr: Further on, from the bright red windows o' the 'Cutlass-Fish Inn,' thar came such fervent rays, dat it seemed t' 'ave melted the packed snow 'n ice from afore the house, fer everywhere else the congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,rather weary fer me, when I struck me foot against the flinty projections, 'cause from hard, remorseless service the soles o' me boots were in a most miserable plight.

en: Too expensive and jolly, again thought I, pausing one moment to watch the broad glare in the street, and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses within.
pr: Too expensive 'n jolly, again thought I, pausin' one moment t' watch the broad glare in the road, 'n hear the sounds o' the tinklin' glasses within.

en: But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; dont you hear? get away from before the door; your patched boots are stopping the way.
pr: But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; dont ye hear? get away from afore the door; yer patched boots be stoppin' the way.

en: So on I went.
pr: So on I went.

en: I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward, for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.
pr: I now by instinct followed the roads dat took me waterward, fer thar, prolly, were the cheapest, if nah the cheeriest inns.

en: Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand, and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb.
pr: Such dreary roads! blocks o' blackness, nah houses, on either hand, 'n here 'n thar a candle, like a candle movin' about in a tomb.

en: At this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of the town proved all but deserted.
pr: At dis hour o' the night, o' the last day o' the week, dat quarter o' the town proved nigh-on deserted.

en: Besides though New Bedford has of late been gradually monopolising the business of whaling, and though in this matter poor old Nantucket is now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great originalthe Tyre of this Carthage;the place where the first dead American whale was stranded.
pr: Aye, though New Bedford has o' late been gradually monopolizin' the business o' whalin', 'n though in this matter poor ol' Nantucket be now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great original—the Tyre o' this Carthage; the place where the first dead American whale was marooned.

en: Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to give chase to the Leviathan?
pr: Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal whalemen, the Red-Maties, first sally out in canoes t' give chase t' the Leviathan?

en: And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported cobblestonesso goes the storyto throw at the whales, in order to discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the bowsprit?
pr: And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first adventurous wee sloop put forth, partly laden with imported cobblestones—so goes the tale—to throw at the whales, in order t' discover when they were nigh enough t' risk a harpoon from the bowsprit?

en: Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before me in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it became a matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep meanwhile.
pr: Now havin' a night, a day, 'n still another night followin' afore me in New Bedford, ere I could embark fer me destined port, it became a matter o' concern where I was t' eat 'n sleep meanwhile.

en: It was a very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and dismal night, bitingly cold and cheerless.
pr: 'Twas a mighty dubious-lookin', nay, a mighty dark 'n dismal night, bitingly cold 'n cheerless.

en: I knew no one in the place.
pr: I knew no one in the place.

en: With anxious grapnels I had sounded my pocket, and only brought up a few pieces of silver,So, wherever you go, Ishmael, said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of a dreary street shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the north with the darkness towards the southwherever in your wisdom you may conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to inquire the price, and dont be too particular.
pr: With anxious grapnels I had sounded me pocket, 'n only brought up a few pieces o' silver. So, wherever ye go, Ishmael, said I t' meself, as I stood in the middle o' a dreary street shoulderin' me bag, 'n comparin' the gloom towards the north with the darkness towards the south—wherever in yer wisdom ye may conclude t' lodge fer the night, me dear Ishmael, be sure t' inquire the price, 'n don't be too particular.

en: With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of 'The Crossed Harpoons'but it looked too expensive and jolly there.
pr: With haltin' steps I paced the streets, 'n passed the sign o' 'The Crossed Harpoons'—but it looked too expensive 'n jolly there.

en: Further on, from the bright red windows of the 'Sword-Fish Inn,' there came such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the packed snow and ice from before the house, for everywhere else the congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement,rather weary for me, when I struck my foot against the flinty projections, because from hard, remorseless service the soles of my boots were in a most miserable plight.
pr: Further on, from the bright red windows o' the 'Sword-Fish Inn,' there came such fervent rays, that it seemed t' 'ave melted the packed snow 'n ice from afore the house, fer everywhere else the congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic pavement—rather weary fer me, when I struck me foot against the flinty projections, 'cause from hard, remorseless service the soles o' me boots were in a most miserable plight.

en: Too expensive and jolly, again thought I, pausing one moment to watch the broad glare in the street, and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses within.
pr: Too expensive 'n jolly, again thought I, pausin' one moment t' watch the broad glare in the street, 'n hear the sounds o' the tinklin' glasses within.

en: But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; dont you hear? get away from before the door; your patched boots are stopping the way.
pr: But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don't ye hear? get away from afore the door; yer patched boots be stoppin' the way.

en: So on I went.
pr: So on I went.

en: I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward, for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.
pr: I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward, fer there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.

en: Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either hand, and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a tomb.
pr: Such dreary streets! blocks o' blackness, not houses, on either hand, 'n here 'n there a candle, like a candle movin' about in a tomb.

en: At this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that quarter of the town proved all but deserted.
pr: At this hour o' the night, o' the last day o' the week, that quarter o' the town proved all but deserted.

en: But presently I came to a smoky light proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which stood invitingly open.
pr: But presently I came t' a smoky light proceedin' from a low, wide buildin', the door o' which stood invitingly open.

en: It had a careless look, as if it were meant for the uses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was to stumble over an ash-box in the porch.
pr: It had a careless look, as if it were meant fer the uses o' the public; so, boardin', the first thing I did was t' stumble o'er an ash-box in the poop deck.

en: Ha! thought I, ha, as the flying particles almost choked me, are these ashes from that destroyed city, Gomorrah?
pr: Har! thought I, ha, as the flyin' particles nigh-on choked me, be these ashes from dat destroyed city, Gomorrah?

en: But 'The Crossed Harpoons,' and 'The Sword-Fish?'this, then must needs be the sign of 'The Trap.'
pr: But 'The Crossed Harpoons,' 'n 'The Sabre-Fish?'dis, then must needs be the sign o' 'The Trap.'

en: However, I picked myself up and hearing a loud voice within, pushed on and opened a second, interior door.
pr: Howe'er, I picked meself up 'n hearin' a loud voice within, pushed on 'n opened a second, interior door.

en: It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet.
pr: It seemed the great Black Parliament sittin' in Tophet.

en: Squire Trelawney, Doctor Livesey, and the rest of these gentlemen having asked me to write down the whole particulars about Treasure Island, from the beginning to the end, keeping nothing back but the bearings of the island, and that only because there is still treasure not yet lifted.
pr: Squire Trelawney, Doctor Livesey, an' th' rest o' these fine gents asked me t' jot down th' whole tale 'o Treasure Island, from start t' finish, keepin' nothin' back 'cept th' bearings o' th' isle, only 'cause thar be treasure still not yet taken!

en: I take up my pen in the year of grace 17—, and go back to the time when my father kept the 'Admiral Benbow' Inn, and the brown old seaman, with the saber cut, first took up his lodging under our roof.
pr: I be takin' up me pen in th' year o' grace 17—, goin' back t' when me father kept th' 'Admiral Benbow' Inn, an' th' brown ol' sea dog, wi' a saber cut, first took up lodgin' under our roof.

en: I remember him as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow; a tall, strong, heavy, nut-brown man.
pr: I recall him as if it be yest'rday, comin' ploddin' t' th' inn door, his sea-chest in tow on a hand-barrow; a tall, stout, nut-brown man.

en: His tarry pig-tail falling over the shoulders of his soiled blue coat; his hands ragged and scarred, with black, broken nails, and the saber cut across one cheek, a dirty, livid white.
pr: His tarry pigtail draped o'er his soiled blue coat, his hands ragged an' scarred, black broken nails, an' that saber cut across his cheek, dirty 'n' white as a ghost.

en: I remember him looking round the cove and whistling to himself as he did so, and then breaking out in that old sea-song that he sang so often afterwards.
pr: I remember him gazin' round th' cove, whistlin' t' himself, then breakin' into that ol' sea tune he sang often aft.

en: "Fifteen men on the dead man's chest, Yo-ho-ho and a bottle of rum!"
pr: "Fifteen men on th' dead man's chest, Yo-ho-ho an' a bottle o' rum!"

en: I remember him as if it were yesterday as he came plodding to the inn door in the high, old tottering voice that seemed to have been tuned and broken at the capstan bars.
pr: I recall him as if 'twas yest'rday, comin' ploddin' t' th' inn door in that high, totterin' voice o' his, tuned an' broken at th' capstan bars.

en: Then he rapped on the door with a bit of stick like a handspike that he carried, and when my father appeared, called roughly for a glass of rum.
pr: Then he gave th' door a rap wi' a stick like a handspike he carried, an' when me father appeared, he called rough-like fer a glass o' rum.

en: This, when it was brought to him, he drank slowly, like a connoisseur, lingering on the taste, and still looking about him at the cliffs and up at our signboard.
pr: When it were brought t' him, he drank it slow, like a true connoisseur, lingerin' on th' taste, lookin' 'bout at th' cliffs an' our signboard.

en: "This is a handy cove," says he, at length; "and a pleasant sittyated grog-shop. Much company, mate?"
pr: "This be a handy cove," says he, at length; "an' a right pleasant grog-shop. Much company, matey?"

en: My father told him no, very little company, the more was the pity.
pr: Me father told him nay, not much company, pity that be.

en: "Well, then," said he, "this is the berth for me. Here you, matey," he cried to the man who trundled the barrow; "bring up alongside and help up my chest. I'll stay here a bit," he continued.
pr: "Well, then," says he, "this be th' berth fer me. Oi, you matey," he cries t' th' man with th' barrow; "bring it here an' haul up me chest. I'll be stayin' here fer a spell," he goes on.

en: "I'm a plain man; rum and bacon and eggs is what I want, and that head up there for to watch ships off."
pr: "I be a plain man; rum, bacon, an' eggs be what I want, an' that there headland t' watch ships from."

en: "What you mought call me? You mought call me captain. Oh, I see what you're at—there," and he threw down three or four gold pieces on the threshold.
pr: "What ye might call me? Ye might call me captain. Ah, I see yer point—there," an' he tossed down three or four gold pieces on th' threshold.

en: "You can tell me when I've worked through that," said he, looking as fierce as a commander.
pr: "Ye can tell me when I've run through that lot," says he, lookin' fierce as a commander.

en: And, indeed, bad as his clothes were, and coarsely as he spoke, he had none of the appearance of a man who sailed before the mast, but seemed like a mate or skipper, accustomed to be obeyed or to strike.
pr: An' truth be told, rough as his garb an' tongue were, he had none o' th' look o' a man who sailed afore th' mast, more like a mate or skipper, used t' bein' obeyed or handin' out blows.

en: The man who came with the barrow told us the mail had set him down the morning before at the 'Royal George'; that he had inquired what inns there were along the coast, and hearing ours well spoken of, I suppose, and described as lonely, had chosen it from the others for his place of residence.
pr: Th' man wi' th' barrow told us th' mail dropped him at th' 'Royal George' yestermorn; he asked 'bout inns 'long th' coast, heard ours spoke well of, I reckon, an' picked it as his lodgin', bein' nice an' lonely.

en: And that was all we could learn of our guest.
pr: An' that be all we could learn 'bout our guest.

en: He was a very silent man by custom.
pr: Aye, he be a quiet man by nature.

en: All day he hung round the cove, or upon the cliffs, with a brass telescope; all evening he sat in a corner of the parlor next the fire, and drank rum and water very strong.
pr: All day he lingered 'round th' cove, or up on th' cliffs wi' a brass spyglass; all night he sat in th' parlor corner by th' fire, drinkin' strong rum an' water.

en: Mostly he would not speak when spoken to; only look up sudden and fierce, and blow through his nose like a fog-horn.
pr: Mostly he'd keep mum when spoken t'; only look up sudden an' fierce, an' blow through his nose like a fog-horn.

en: And we and the people who came about our house soon learned to let him be.
pr: We an' th' folk who came 'round our house soon learned t' let him be.

en: Every day, when he came back from his stroll, he would ask if any seafaring men had gone by along the road.
pr: Each day, after his stroll, he'd ask if any sea-lovin' men had passed along th' road.

en: At first we thought it was the want of company of his own kind that made him ask this question; but at last we began to see he was desirous to avoid them.
pr: At first we thought he was lonely fer his own kind, but at last we saw he wanted t' steer clear o' them.

en: When a seaman put up at the 'Admiral Benbow' (as now and then some did, making by the coast road for Bristol) he would look in at him through the curtained door before he entered the parlor; and he was always sure to be as silent as a mouse when any such was present.
pr: When a sailor dropped anchor at th' 'Admiral Benbow' (as now an' then some did, makin' fer Bristol by th' coast road) he'd peek in at him through th' curtained door afore he entered th' parlor; an' he'd be quiet as a mouse when any such was present.

en: For me, at least, there was no secret about the matter, for I was, in a way, a sharer in his alarms.
pr: Fer me, at least, thar be no secret 'bout th' matter, fer I was, in a way, a sharer in his alarms.

en: Hello, how are you today
pr: Ahoy, how ye be farin' today, matey?

en: Then he rapped on the door with a bit of stick like a handspike that he carried, and when my father appeared, called roughly for a glass of rum.
pr: Then he gave th' door a rap wi' a stick like a handspike he carried, an' when me father appeared, he called rough-like fer a glass o' rum.

en: This, when it was brought to him, he drank slowly, like a connoisseur, lingering on the taste, and still looking about him at the cliffs and up at our signboard.
pr: When it were brought t' him, he drank it slow, like a true connoisseur, lingerin' on th' taste, lookin' 'bout at th' cliffs an' our signboard.

en: "This is a handy cove," says he, at length; "and a pleasant sittyated grog-shop. Much company, mate?"
pr: "This be a handy cove," says he, at length; "an' a right pleasant grog-shop. Much company, matey?"

en: My father told him no, very little company, the more was the pity.
pr: Me father told him nay, not much company, pity that be.

en: "Well, then," said he, "this is the berth for me. Here you, matey," he cried to the man who trundled the barrow; "bring up alongside and help up my chest. I'll stay here a bit," he continued.
pr: "Well, then," says he, "this be th' berth fer me. Oi, you matey," he cries t' th' man with th' barrow; "bring it here an' haul up me chest. I'll be stayin' here fer a spell," he goes on.

en: "I'm a plain man; rum and bacon and eggs is what I want, and that head up there for to watch ships off."
pr: "I be a plain man; rum, bacon, an' eggs be what I want, an' that there headland t' watch ships from."

en: "What you mought call me? You mought call me captain. Oh, I see what you're at—there," and he threw down three or four gold pieces on the threshold.
pr: "What ye might call me? Ye might call me captain. Ah, I see yer point—there," an' he tossed down three or four gold pieces on th' threshold.

en: "You can tell me when I've worked through that," said he, looking as fierce as a commander.
pr: "Ye can tell me when I've run through that lot," says he, lookin' fierce as a commander.

en: And, indeed, bad as his clothes were, and coarsely as he spoke, he had none of the appearance of a man who sailed before the mast, but seemed like a mate or skipper, accustomed to be obeyed or to strike.
pr: An' truth be told, rough as his garb an' tongue were, he had none o' th' look o' a man who sailed afore th' mast, more like a mate or skipper, used t' bein' obeyed or handin' out blows.

en: The man who came with the barrow told us the mail had set him down the morning before at the 'Royal George'; that he had inquired what inns there were along the coast, and hearing ours well spoken of, I suppose, and described as lonely, had chosen it from the others for his place of residence.
pr: Th' man wi' th' barrow told us th' mail dropped him at th' 'Royal George' yestermorn; he asked 'bout inns 'long th' coast, heard ours spoke well of, I reckon, an' picked it as his lodgin', bein' nice an' lonely.

en: And that was all we could learn of our guest.
pr: An' that be all we could learn 'bout our guest.

en: He was a very silent man by custom.
pr: Aye, he be a quiet man by nature.

en: All day he hung round the cove, or upon the cliffs, with a brass telescope; all evening he sat in a corner of the parlor next the fire, and drank rum and water very strong.
pr: All day he lingered 'round th' cove, or up on th' cliffs wi' a brass spyglass; all night he sat in th' parlor corner by th' fire, drinkin' strong rum an' water.

en: Mostly he would not speak when spoken to; only look up sudden and fierce, and blow through his nose like a fog-horn.
pr: Mostly he'd keep mum when spoken t'; only look up sudden an' fierce, an' blow through his nose like a fog-horn.

en: And we and the people who came about our house soon learned to let him be.
pr: We an' th' folk who came 'round our house soon learned t' let him be.

en: Every day, when he came back from his stroll, he would ask if any seafaring men had gone by along the road.
pr: Each day, after his stroll, he'd ask if any sea-lovin' men had passed along th' road.

en: At first we thought it was the want of company of his own kind that made him ask this question; but at last we began to see he was desirous to avoid them.
pr: At first we thought he wanted company o' his own kind, but soon we saw he was keen t' avoid 'em.

en: When a seaman put up at the 'Admiral Benbow' (as now and then some did, making by the coast road for Bristol), he would look in at him through the curtained door before he entered the parlor.
pr: When a seaman put up at th' 'Admiral Benbow' (now an' then one did, bound for Bristol), he'd peer in at 'em through th' curtain 'fore enterin' th' parlor.

en: And he was always sure to be as silent as a mouse when any such was present.
pr: An' he were always quiet as a mouse when any o' that sort were about.

en: For me, at least, there was no secret about the matter; for I was, in a way, a sharer in his alarms.
pr: As fer me, there be no secret 'bout it; I were, in a way, a partner in his fears.

en: Holmes had the impersonal joy of the true artist in his better work, even as he mourned darkly when it fell below the high level to which he aspired.
pr: Holmes had the scurvy joy o' the true swashbuckler in his better booty, even as he cursed the seven seas when it fell below the high tide o' his expectations.

en: He was still chuckling over his success when Billy swung open the door and Inspector MacDonald of Scotland Yard was ushered into the room.
pr: He were still cacklin' like a parrot over his plunder when Billy swung open the door and Inspector MacDonald o' Scotland Yard were ushered into the great hall.

en: Those were the early days at the end of the ’80’s, when Alec MacDonald was far from having attained the national fame which he has now achieved.
pr: Those were the early days o' plunderin' and pillagin' at the end o' the 80's, when Alec MacDonald were far from havin' earned his place among the most feared buccaneers on the seven seas.

en: He was a young but trusted member of the detective force, who had distinguished himself in several cases which had been intrusted to him.
pr: He were a young swabbie but trusted member o' the detective crew, who had earned his stripes in several battles against the scurvy dogs o' crime.

en: His tall, bony figure gave promise of exceptional physical strength, while his great cranium and deep-set, lustrous eyes spoke no less clearly of the keen intelligence which twinkled out from behind his bushy eyebrows.
pr: His tall, lanky frame gave promise o' exceptional physical strength, while his great noggin and deep-set, sparklin' peepers spoke no less clearly o' the keen wits which twinkled out from behind his bushy eyebrows, like a barnacle on a sunken ship.

en: He was a silent, precise man with a dour nature and a hard Aberdonian accent.
pr: He were a silent, precise scallywag with a dour nature and a hard Aberdonian brogue, like a sea dog who'd spent too many years at sea.

en: Twice already in his career had Holmes helped him to attain success, his own sole reward being the intellectual joy of the problem.
pr: Twice already in his career had Holmes helped him to find the hidden treasure, his own sole booty bein' the intellectual joy o' the puzzle.

en: For this reason the affection and respect of the Scotchman for his amateur colleague were profound, and he showed them by the frankness with which he consulted Holmes in every difficulty.
pr: For this reason the affection and respect o' the Scotchman for his amateur mate were as deep as the ocean, and he showed them by the frankness with which he sought out Holmes' counsel in every stormy weather.

en: Mediocrity knows nothing higher than itself; but talent instantly recognizes genius, and MacDonald had talent enough for his profession to enable him to perceive that there was no humiliation in seeking the assistance of one who already stood alone in Europe, both in his gifts and in his experience.
pr: Mediocrity knows nothin' higher than itself, but talent instantly recognizes genius, and MacDonald had the talent o' a true buccaneer to enable him to see that there were no shame in seekin' the help o' one who already ruled the seven seas, both in his plunderin' and in his battle-hardened experience.

en: Holmes was not prone to friendship, but he was tolerant of the big Scotchman, and smiled at the sight of him.
pr: Holmes were not prone to makin' friends, but he were tolerant o' the big Scotchman, and smiled at the sight o' him, like a sea captain who'd found a rare gem on a deserted isle.

en: ‘You are an early bird, Mr. Mac,’ said he. ‘I wish you luck with your worm. I fear this means that there is some mischief afoot.’
pr: ‘Ye be an early bird, Mr. Mac,’ said he. ‘I wish ye luck with yer worm. I fear this means that there be some scurvy business brewin’.’

pr: Aye, matey, I be as mixed up as a mess o' seaweed.
